Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: An open class is scheduled at the school, and the father should attend
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the long line at the polling station, glancing at my watch for the third time in as many minutes. My daughter’s open class was starting soon, and she had begged me to be there. “Please, Daddy, I want you to see my project!” she’d said, her eyes shining with hope. I promised I wouldn’t miss it. But now, as I inched forward, an official called out, “Voters with last names A–M, please move to the new line on the left.” My last name started with B. The new line looked longer, but the official’s voice was firm—this was the rule. I felt the weight of my civic duty pressing on me; I wanted to set a good example for my kids about following instructions and participating in democracy. But every minute spent here was a minute lost from my daughter’s big day. My heart pounded as I hesitated, torn between being the reliable father she needed and the responsible citizen I wanted to be.
